title: What Does “Training to Independence” Mean for Cryo-EM?
content: The Pacific Northwest Cryo-EM Center (PNCC) was created in 2018 by the NIH Common Fund Transformative High-Resolution Cryo-electron Microscopy Program to promote access and training to high-end cryo-electron microscopy [1]. Our overall training mandate was to focus on training groups to independence, which at PNCC we approached with an emphasis on “hands-on” training opportunities that cover practical skills needed when doing cryo-EM experiments. Over the past six years, PNCC has created and run many such training workshops that cover most of the single-particle cryo-EM workflow [2] from grid preparation to data processing. Of course, these training efforts also included substantial collaboration with a working group of other cryo-EM centers (NCCAT [3] and S2C2 [4]) as well as cryo-EM curriculum developers (CryoEM 101 [5], Getting Started in CryoEM [6], CryoVR [7], CryoEDU [8], Principles of CryoEM [9]). The team effort needed to integrate all this training content and workshops occurred is what nucleated the cryo-EM merit badge program [10].
